author: Karen Crouse
title: Relentless Schedule Chips Away at Rory McIlroy’s Drive to Improve - The New York Times
text:
Continue reading the main story Share This Page Continue reading the main story Continue reading the main story NAPA, Calif. — Rory McIlroy’s success is built on quick calculations, such as determining the yardage he has left to the flag after a booming drive on a long par 4. But the math did not add up on the column of figures he was recently studying.
In a 365-day span, McIlroy spent 287 nights in hotels and the equivalent of 14 days on airplanes. An accounting of a recent 12-month chunk of his life revealed that McIlroy had 18 days off after fulfilling his professional obligations. He hardly had enough time to recharge, much less refine his game.
The continuous loop of golf seasons creates a time crunch that is especially acute for McIlroy, who is starting a new season on the PGA Tour this week at the Frys.com Open before heading abroad for the conclusion of the 2015 European Tour campaign.
Continue reading the main story Related Coverage Bill Haas Helps American Team Secure Sixth Straight Presidents Cup OCT. 11, 2015 Internationals Close Gap at Presidents Cup OCT. 9, 2015 Since the start of the calendar year, McIlroy has seen his world ranking slip from No. 1 to No. 3, behind Jordan Spieth and Jason Day. Their superior short games, McIlroy said, caused him to address in practice “a few of the areas that I’m not maybe quite as good as they are.”

Ball-striking carried McIlroy to the summit and kept him there for 95 nonconsecutive weeks. His fall prompted him to reassess his approach of spending more time on the range than on the green. Like many athletes, McIlroy prefers the ego boost of working on what he does well to the discomfort of confronting his shortcomings.
On Wednesday, he appeared committed to following the example of Phil Mickelson, who took what he had read in a college psychology text about overcoming a fear by facing it and applied it to golf by working on uncomfortable shots until they become strengths.
